Graphical abstract In this work, we analyzed the role of the interactions involved in the reaction mechanism for the transesterification of ethyl acetate and methanol on the pore mouth of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst. The Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) was applied for the analysis of adsorbate-catalyst interactions in order to gain a deeper understanding about the relationship between bonding and catalytic properties along the reaction coordinate and the role of weak interactions in the catalytic activity. Experimental FT-IR spectrum was supported by the theoretical model for the coadsorption of both reagents following a dual-site mechanism. Our results reveal that the key role of the (CTA+)(SiO−) ion pair is to stabilize the reactant species. During the reaction coordinate, the silica and the head of the surfactant are bonded through several O···H(CH3) interactions forming the bifunctional active site on the surface of the solid catalyst. Four interactions are associated with the reaction mechanism. The rest of weak adsorbate-catalysts interactions along the reaction coordinate are related to the additional stabilization of the reactants on the pore mouth of the catalyst. Keywords Bifunctional catalytic site Transesterification reaction Heterogeneous basic catalysis DFT Quantum theory of atoms in molecules 1 Introduction Among the main objectives of research in the chemical industry, the development of green chemistry requires a careful planning of a molecular design and chemical synthesis [1]. One of the Principles of Green Chemistry is to increase the use of renewable materials and biomass is considered as an available source for this purpose. Furthermore, the use of more selective and innovative catalysts is committed to being a relevant issue. For example, solid catalysts that imitate nature, develop less polluting and more environmentally friendly processes [2,3]. In view of this fact, the production and use of biodiesel has become very attractive as a biofuel [4–6]. The commercial production of biodiesel from vegetable oils/fats by transesterification reaction using methanol (MeOH) with sodium hydroxide (NaOH) or potassium hydroxide (KOH) as homogeneous catalyst is a well-known procedure. However, when transesterification occurs in a homogeneous phase, the catalyst removal is difficult, and the final product separation is costly due to the need for subsequent steps of neutralization and purification. Therefore, several studies have focused on biodiesel production using heterogeneous catalysts [7,8], because of the advantages in terms of the easily separation of the solid catalyst and the reused cycle without loss of activity, as well as the products of reaction are obtained in high purity [3]. Mesoporous molecular sieves of the M41S family are potential heterogeneous catalysts and catalyst supports due to its well-defined pore structure, high surface areas and large pore volumes [9]. Therefore, in recent years the functionalized MCM-41 has been investigated [10–12]. For instance, the MCM-41 bi-functionalized as basic and acid catalysts have been tested in industrial reactions such as Deacetalization–Knoevenagel reactions [13], as well as for base catalyzed Knoevenagel condensation [14,15]. In this regard, it has been demonstrated experimentally, using XRD, SEM, TGA and BET methods, that the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 heterogeneous catalyst has good yields in transesterification reactions of vegetable oils by basic catalysis [16–18]. The [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 is formed by a mesoporous structure of Si-MCM-41 where the structure directing agent [the cetyl-trimethylammonium cation (CTA+)] is kept occluded. Combined experimental and theoretical studies are an innovative approach to understand the relationship between structure and properties of solids [19,20]. In this sense, Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations could be used in order to interpret experimental data with industrial interests. For instance, Gomes et al. have validated experimental results about reactions involved on biomass conversion using zeolites and have clarified the reaction mechanisms on the surface of the catalyst by using theoretical calculations [21–23]. Recently, from a DFT calculation in conjunction with FT-IR analysis, we have explored the role of (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion pair on the catalytic activity of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst demonstrating that the basic site of the silica surface (≡SiO−) and the surfactant molecule (CTA+) generates a bifunctional catalytic site where the reactant molecules are accommodated by a dual site mechanism. Suggesting that, the rupture and formation of bonds occur in concerted way and the species are stabilized through adsorbate-catalyst interactions [24]. However, it remains to analyze the nature and strength of the interactions between reactants and the solid surface, since it has been shown that weak interactions play a crucial role in stabilizing organic reagents on surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts that involve channels and cavities [25,26]. In previous works, we have demonstrated the usefulness of quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) in the study of bond breaking and bond forming processes and adsorbate − catalyst interactions [25–29]. Furthermore, the QTAIM method has gained relevance in recent years in several fields such as conformational analysis, chemical bond, electron delocalization, chemical reactivity, among others [30,31]. For example, the study of cooperativity in supramolecular systems such as self-assembled rosettes [32], as well as systems involving biomacromolecular complexes in drug–receptor and enzyme–substrate interactions [33,34]. In particular, under a rational drug design approach, interactions should be analyzed rigorously and quantitatively. Similarly, in catalysis, a deep understanding of the chemical concepts helps to extract conclusions on the studied system. Those concepts, such as the chemical bond and adsorbate − catalyst interactions, inform us of reaction mechanisms and stabilization of reactants on the surface of the catalysts. Furthermore, an approach based on the analysis of interactions is useful in the design and optimization of host-guest systems in heterogeneous catalysis. Previous works have shown that although host-guest interactions inside microporous zeolites are generally weak, all together could support the stabilization of adsorbed species along the reaction coordinate [25]. By analyzing the catalyst adsorbate interactions, it is possible to quantify their contribution to the catalytic activity of the catalyst according to the way in which the species place themselves inside the pore mouth surface or on the top of it. In addition, it is also important to explore the capacity of organic solids and cations to reorganize their charge to minimize the energy of the bound intermediates and transition states [35]. The broader significance of this work lies in the understanding and control, at the molecular scale, long-range interactions for chemical reactivity at localized structures on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the aim of this work is to analyze the role of key interactions involved in the proposed reaction mechanism for the transesterification reaction of ethyl acetate and methanol on the pore mouth of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst. Such key interactions were investigated, with the principles of QTAIM, to explain the stabilization mode of the species reactants, on the pore mouth of the catalyst. Comparison between FT-IR experimental spectrum for adsorbed species on the surface mesoporous solid and calculated theoretical vibrational frequencies support the assignment and the interpretation of the experimental peaks. 2 Methodology 2.1 Experimental The [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 was synthesized following the methodology proposed by Grün [36], using reagent stoichiometry 1 TEOS: 0.3 CTABr : 92 H2O : 26 CH3CH2OH : 41 NH4OH. The detailed synthesis procedure can be found in our previous works [17,18]. Experimental analyzes for Methanol and Ethyl Acetate adsorbed on molecular sieves were performed through Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR), performed on equipment PerkinElmer Spectrum 65 with accessory ATR, at wavelengths of 600 to 4000 cm−1 and resolution of 0.5 cm−1. 2.2 Theoretical calculation details In order to model a transesterification reaction of vegetal oils, we adopted the methanolysis of ethyl acetate (EtAc) as a study case. For the study of the reaction, we used the cluster approach (employing a representative catalyst cluster cut out from the periodic model [37]). We opted for use reduced models because between the different approaches to model adsorption at surfaces [38], several cluster models were successfully used by several authors to simulated silica surfaces [39–43]. For instance, Nuñez-Zarur et al. [41] compared a 2T (two SiO4 units) with a larger 9T (nine SiO4 units) cluster model, as well as the periodic model for the alkane metathesis catalyzed by silica-supported tantalum hydrides. They found that geometries in all stationary points remain very similar for the cluster and periodic models, and the energies of the selected intermediates and transition states show the same general trends. Thus, they concluded that the small 2T model appears to be a reasonably accurate model allowing a large exploration of reaction pathways. Besides, the use of cluster models has been widely employed in the study of chemical reactions mediated by catalysts, such as mesoporous molecular sieves [41,44–47]. Furthermore, the properties under study in this work are local in nature and do not depend on long-range interactions or on structural features specifically due to the extended nature of the system (i.e., infinite H-bond chains). Thus, the cluster model used in this research for the study of adsorption/reaction of organic molecules on a single active site and, to explore the role of adsorbate-catalyst interactions ensure validity to our results. The cluster models used here were described in detail in our previous work [24]. The [C4TA+]-6T_SiO− and [C6TA+]-10T_SiO− catalyst models, contain two pairs of CnTA+ cation (n = 4, 6) from the structure-directing agent model coupled to two free siloxy anions (6T and 10T cluster) from the Si-MCM-41 mesoporous silica model respectively, as a way to consider the surface of the pore mouth where it has been postulated that the reaction occurs. To the best of our knowledge, there are no computational studies (besides our previous work) focusing on the study of models of transesterification reaction on [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations at Becke3 Lee–Yang–Parr (B3LYP) level [48,49], with the 6–31G** basis set were carried out using the Gaussian09 software program [50]. This functional was previously used to model amorphous silica surfaces [37,40]. The single point energies were obtained at B3LYP/6−31++G(D,P)//B3LYP/6−31 G(D,P) calculations. All stationary points were characterized by calculating the Hessian matrix and analyzing the vibrational normal modes. Intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations were performed to confirm the connection between reactants and products. The reaction path was followed employing the IRC algorithm [51,52], as implemented in Gaussian 09 [50]. A step size of 0.01 amu−1/2 bohr was used according to previous work [24,28]. The QTAIM calculations based on the topological analysis of the electron density was employed to locate bond critical points (BCP), ring critical points (RCP) and cage critical points (CCP) [53–55]. The most meaningful BCP respect to the reaction and the adsorbate-catalyst interactions were characterized by the properties of the electron density [ρ(r)], the Laplacian of the electron density [∇2 ρ(r)] and the total energy density [H(r)]. Total electron densities were obtained at B3LYP level using a 6–31++G** basis set and the Gaussian09 program [50]. The local properties at the BCPs were computed using the AIMALL software [56]. The Bader’s net atomic charges were determined on selected atoms using multiwfn software [57]. The accuracy of the integration over the atomic basin (Ω) was assessed by the magnitude of a function q(Ω), which in all cases is less than 10−5 au. for H atoms and 10–4 au. for other atoms. 3 Results and discussion Previous work reported the existence of a bifunctional site that allow the combined adsorption of ethyl acetate and methanol in a concerted way [24]. Fig. 1 displays the energy profile for the formation reaction of the unstable tetrahedral intermediate involved in transesterification reactions with [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst following the dual site mechanism (Langmuir-Hinshelwood model, LH) where the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion pair favors that both reactants adsorb in a concerted way starting the reaction. The concerted mechanism has been reported in our previous work and it will be discussed only briefly [24]. In this mechanism, MeOH reacts directly with the ethyl acetate in a single step to form the unstable tetrahedral intermediate, thus, OM-HM bond breaking and OM-C1 bond forming occur simultaneously in one step as the reaction proceeds. Following the reaction coordinate, the initial step starts with the physisorption of both molecules, methanol on the basic site of the silica surfaces and ethyl acetate on the acid side of CTA+ giving rise to the ethyl acetate/methanol coadsorbed complex. Thus, the carbonyl oxygen of EtAc (Oc) interacts with the acid site located between the two surfactant molecules, and methanol interacts with the oxygen atom of the basic site denoted as O1 and thus, the oxygen of methanol (OM) is oriented towards the carbon atom of carbonyl bond (C1). Adsorption energies (ΔE ads_EtAc/MeOH) calculated at B3LYP/6–31++G(d,p)//B3LYP/6−31 G(d,p) level are –28.7 and –25.7 kcal mol−1 for [C4TA+]-6T_SiO– and [C6TA+]-10T_SiO− models, respectively. 3.1 Theoretical and experimental study of the vibrational spectrum of adsorbed complex Fig. 2 shows FT-IR results for methanol and ethyl acetate adsorbed on the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 molecular sieve (black lines) and the calculated theoretical vibrational frequencies (red lines). The bands between 785 and 1030 cm−1 are related to the vibrational bands of the Si–O-Si group, referring to the catalyst silicon and oxygen structures. For the isolated catalyst, the same ones were reported at 792 cm−1 [24] and around 1221−1240 cm−1 respectively [24,58,59]. Therefore, after the adsorption process, vSiO- band decrease and shifts toward higher wavenumbers. The corresponding vibration bands of the ethyl acetate group CO and CO can be observed at 1214 and 1735 cm−1. At 1374 and 1479 cm−1 the bending bands of the CH2 and CH3 (δCH2 and δCH3) groups present in methanol, ethyl acetate and also the [CTA+] directing agent are observed and, between 2827 to 2974 cm−1, the vibrational bands of the CH2 and CH3 groups (vas CH2, vas CH3, vs CH2, vs CH3). The values are mostly similar except for vas Si-O-Si and vs CH3 (see Table S2 of the Supplementary Material section). It is observed from Fig. 2, that the calculated frequencies differ from the observed experimental values by an average of less than 100 cm−1, indicating that the experimental FT-IR spectra may be supported by the theoretically calculated values. The band at 3338 cm−1 can be attributed to the hydroxyl group and also interactions of the ethyl acetate and methanol −OH groups by hydrogen bonds with other groups present in the sample, such as carbonyl and possible presence of humidity in the samples. The theoretical frequency for vOH (2956 cm−1) is noticeably more distant from the experimental frequency, since the interactions mentioned above are not taken into account in theoretical calculations [60–64]. For more clarity, to the comparisons made with the experiment, see the calculated vibrational modes on the video S1 of the Supplementary Material section, and Table S2 that reports the difference between experimental and theoretical values (ΔExp-Theor values). Further evidences that support the validity of the model used here are presented in Supplementary Material section. 3.2 Insights from the electron density analyses into the role of adsorbate-catalyst interactions on the catalytic activity of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 The topological analysis of the electron density was performed for all intermolecular interactions. The molecular graphs of electron density for species involved on the reaction coordinate are shown in Figs. 3–5 , and the corresponding amplified figures showing selected atomic interactions are shown in the Supplementary material section. Only the most meaningful BCP with respect to the reaction and stabilization on the catalyst surface are considered and discussed in detail. Tables 1–4 list the bond distances and the most relevant topological properties of the electron density at the BCP. It is interesting to emphasize, that studies derived from topological properties of the electron density distribution allow association of each interaction with a specific phenomenon of the catalytic process [25,26]. Also, numerous properties that can be calculated at the BCP constitute suitable tools to classify the interactions between fragments [55,65]. Thus, the relationships between bonding and catalytic properties could be clarified by analyzing the electron density of the interaction between reactants and the surface of the catalyst. Therefore, for the QTAIM analysis we subdivided the adsorbate-catalyst system in four subsystems: the first one is focused on ion-pair interactions, the second one is related to the reaction itself and involves the interactions between the reactants and the bifunctional active site of the catalyst [the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion pair]; the third involves interactions between the organic molecules and the rest of the catalyst and the fourth includes other reactant-reactant interactions. Ion-pair interactions: for the isolated catalyst, each Osiloxy of the silica model interacts with three hydrogen atoms from the methyl groups of the surfactant heads giving rise to six Si-O···H interactions [denoted O1···H(CH3)S1 and O2···H(CH3)S2] and thus, to the formation of the ionic pair. The d X···Y distances range from 1.90 Å to 1.98 Å, showing low ρ(r) values, ∇2 ρ(r) > 0 and H(r) < 0 (see Table 1). These interactions can be considered closed shell interactions (ionic bond) with a partially covalent character. [66] After the adsorption, distances increase, and the ion-pair interactions became weaker (See Table 2 and Fig. 3). At the TS, distances increase and ρ(r) values decrease even more, further the interactions with one of the surfactant molecules (S1) experience more variation than the others (S2) and one of this interaction disappear (Table 3). After the formation of the intermediate, distances also increase and varies from 2.0–2.70 Å (Fig. 5 and Table 4). However, the highest variation is related to interactions with S1 surfactant, also a new O1···H(CH3)S1 interaction appears with other neutral oxygen atom from the silica. In spite of the ρ(r) decreasing at the O···H(CH3) BCPs along the reaction coordinate, the methyl groups of both surfactant heads are forced to rotate a little, in order to preserve major number of ion-pair interactions whenever possible. Summarizing, during the reaction the silica and the head of the surfactant keep bonded through several O···H(CH3) interactions that represent the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion-pair forming the bifunctional active site on the surface of the solid catalyst, which supports that its presence is key for the catalytic activity of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41. (For more details, see Fig. S1 in the Supplementary material section) 3.2.1 Interactions involved on the reaction mechanism For the ethyl acetate/methanol coadsorbed complexes (Table 2 and Fig. 3), the main adsorbate-catalyst interaction is related to the reaction itself (activation of methanol on the basic site of the catalyst) and involved the interaction between the hydroxyl of methanol (HM) and the oxygen of silica anion (O1) denoted O1···HM interaction with a bond distance of about 1.6 Å. For both catalyst models, the electron density values are high, ∇2 ρ(r) are positive and H(r) are negative implying a strong interaction between the methanol molecule and the catalyst. At the TS (see Table 3 and Fig. 4), this O1···HM interaction related to the proton transfer from MeOH to the siloxy anion is shortened and strengthened, showing relatively large values of ρ(r), negative values of ∇2 ρ(r) and H(r), suggesting that the new bond that is being formed at the TS, displays the characteristics of a shared interaction (or covalent in nature). At the intermediate (see Table 4 and Fig. 5), the bond is completely formed and show topological characteristics of a typical OH bond. On the other hand, the OM-HM bond of the coadsorbed complex is elongated in relation to the isolated MeOH and, at the TS, this bond is broken. However, the BCP corresponding to an OM··· HM interaction is still found. Thus, at the TS, the proton of methanol is bonded to both atoms O1···HM···OM and it is di-coordinated. The ρ(r) value of OM···HM is about 2.6 times smaller than the same value in the O1···HM, and ∇2 ρ(r) > 0 and H(r) < 0, showing that the O1···HM bond forming is stronger than OM···HM bond breaking. In other words, the proton transfer is more advanced towards the intermediate. Following the formation of the intermediate, the OM···HM distance increases [d (X···Y) =1.83 Å] and the interaction weakens showing characteristics of a closed shell interaction (however, the covalent character remains during the reaction). This implies that the unstable intermediate is stabilized by the basic site of the ion-pair. Also, a new BCP is found at the TS between ethylacetate and methanol, giving rise to a new OM···C1 interaction. Their topological properties [ρ(r) = 0.08 au.; ∇2 ρ(r) = 0.12 au.; H(r) < 0] indicated a closed shell interaction with some covalent character. At the intermediate, the d (X···Y) decrease, ρ(r) values increase and ∇2 ρ(r) < 0. The negative value of H(r) suggest large electron sharing between both molecules (covalent bond), then at this step, the main bond of the unstable tetrahedral intermediate was formed. In general, the larger the ρ(r) value, the stronger the bond [53,54]. Interestingly, the Cl-Oc double bond of the ethylacetate also shows changes along the reaction coordinate with distances that varies from 1.22 in the coadsorbed complex to 1.29 in the intermediate. The ρ(r) values decrease (from 0.40 au. to 0.36 au.), Laplacian values also decreases (from -0.03 au. to -0.71 au.) and H(r) values do not change significantly in the course of the reaction keeping their covalent character. These results suggest that the carbonyl oxygen atom is interacting with the acid site on the surfactant zone. Fig. 6 shows the contour maps of negative values of the Laplacian [-∇2 ρ(r)] in the plane that contains the O1, OM and C1 atoms involved on the reaction. At first, it can be observed that, along the reaction coordinate the O1···HM interaction lies into a region of depletion of electron density [∇2 ρ(r)> 0], in correspondence with a closed shell interaction, and then at the TS it changes and lies into a zone of concentration of electron density [∇2 ρ(r) < 0]. The opposite is observed for the HM···OM interaction. Also, the switch of Laplacian character between C1 and OM implies a reorganization of the electron density which favors the new bond formation. 3.2.2 Stabilization by adsorbate-catalyst interactions Along the reaction coordinate several weak adsorbate-catalysts interactions (mainly hydrogen bonding interactions) are also observed, we related the same ones to the additional stabilization of both reactants on the surface of catalyst or pore mouth. (For more details, see Figs. S2–S4 of the Supplementary Material.) In a previous work, we suggested that the carbonyl oxygen atom of EtAc interacts with both head and tail of both surfactant molecules [24], herein we prove this hypothesis on the basis of an electron density analysis. At the coadsorbed complex, four Oc···H interactions between the carbonyl oxygen and the H atoms of the surfactant (head and tail) are found [for example, Oc···H(CS1t) interaction where, H(CS1t) refer to the interaction with the hydrogen atom bounded to a carbon atom of the surfactant tail]. The d X···Y range from 2.3 Å to 2.9 Å and ρ(r), ∇2 ρ(r) and H(r) values are positive showing characteristic of closed-shell interactions. Also, a BCP between the ester oxygen (Oe) and other H of the surfactant is found [denoted Oe···H(CS1h) interaction], this interaction also shows characteristic of closed-shell interactions. Additionally, other two O···H interactions are found between other oxygen atoms of the silica and H of methanol. For the [C4TA+]-6T_SiO− model, two additional H···H interactions are also observed, involving one hydrogen atom from the surfactant head and other hydrogen atom from the organic molecule, these show low electron densities values and H(r) > 0 which refer to weak Van der Waals interactions. Summing up, nine and six adsorbate-catalyst interactions stabilized the coadsorbed complexes of ethyl acetate/methanol for [C4TA+]-6T_SiO− and [C6TA+]-10T_SiO- models, respectively. From the electron density properties at the BCPs, the observed ranges show that all interactions correspond to closed shell interactions. They contribute significantly to the stabilization of the coadsorbed complex and can be rationalized in terms of their relative contribution to the total process. Considering the sum of the total electron density (ρT) of these interactions plus the O1-HM interaction due to the reaction (but also considered an adsorbate-catalyst interaction), the first ones represent 55.3 % and 43.5 % of total density contribution for each catalyst model, respectively. The observed difference is attributed to the number of weak interactions. That is, in the smaller model of catalyst the contribution of weak interactions is more important than that of reaction, while in the larger model the opposite is observed. This may be because the [C6TA+]-10T_SiO- model catalyst has greater mobility restrictions than [C4TA+]-6T_SiO-, so there are fewer atoms available to interact with the reacting species. However, in both cases an important contribution from weak interactions is appreciable. Therefore, in the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst, where the atoms would not be restricted in mobility, the contribution from weak interactions will be more significant. These results demonstrate that EtAc accommodates over the positive potential zone of the ion-pair in order to maximize and optimize the number of interactions that stabilize the coadsorbed complex and to fits properly for the next step of the reaction (TS formation). Therefore, the carbonyl oxygen atom is four-coordinated by four H atoms of the surfactant (head and tail) over the positive potential zone of the ion-pair. Over the negative potential zone of the catalyst, the oxygens of the silica display an opposite behavior acting as a basic site interacting strongly with hydrogens of methanol. At the TS (Table 3 and Fig. 4), the Oc···H interactions decrease to three for the [C4TA+]-6T_SiO− model, distances also decrease and H(r) < 0. Bonds with positive values of ∇2 ρ(r) and small negative values of H(r) at BCP are termed as partially covalent in nature. Also, the Oe···H(CS1h) interaction is strengthened (and for the [C6TA+]-10T_SiO− model disappears). That is, these interactions are stronger than the same ones at the coadsorbed complex, thus they strengthened in the TS. On the other hand, the two O···H(CM) interactions are longer and weaker than in the previous step (only one on [C6TA+]-10T_SiO− model). One adsorbate-catalyst interaction between OM and atoms of the catalyst is found for each catalyst model, where the OM···H(CS1h) interaction for the [C6TA+]-10T_SiO− model shows a partially covalent character. Thus, seven adsorbate-catalyst interactions stabilized both TS. It is interesting to point out that although they are less than those reported for the coadsorbed complex, however, they are stronger. At the intermediate (Table 4 and Fig. 5), several Oc···H interactions can still be observed, some of them with partially covalent character. As we stated above, the CO bond is elongated along the reaction coordinate and this bond weakening which evidence that the carbonyl oxygen atom of the EtAc fragment is interacting with the head and tail of both surfactant fragment from the catalyst. Furthermore, two Oe···H interactions help to stabilize this unstable intermediate. On the other hand, the methanol fragment on the adsorbed intermediate is stabilized by O···H(CM) interactions with the silica fragment and by the H(CM)···H(CS2h) or H(CM)···CS2h interactions with the surfactant fragment from the catalyst. In summary, the contact of the organic molecule with the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst takes place through nine or eight adsorbate-catalyst interactions according to the catalyst model. Therefore, our results indicate that the catalytic phenomenon is located on the surface of the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion-pair and on the nearest local surface region under both organic molecules. They also prove the key role of the intermolecular interactions between the organic molecules and the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst in stabilizing the species along the reaction coordinate. 3.2.3 Other reactant-reactant interactions In addition to the interaction between OM and C1 responsible for the formation of the intermediate through the OM-C1 bond, also other interactions between both reactants are identified. At the coadsorbed complex, two OM···H interactions with C2 and C3 are found. The same ones fulfill a dual purpose. Firstly, they help to suitably orientate MeOH in order to be adsorbed on the basic site. Secondly, the OM···H interactions help the proper orientation between OM and C1 in order to allow the CO bond formation on the next step of the reaction. Both interactions show characteristic of strong Hydrogen bonds with positive values of ∇2 ρ(r) and negative values of H(r) [66]. At the TS also one weak interaction is found for the largest catalyst model. 3.2.4 Analyses from net atomic charges In Table 5 , the net atomic charges, q(Ω), of selected atoms in the site of the reaction are shown. The QTAIM analysis allows a rigorous definition of the charges of the atoms and provides an accurate basis for comparison between reactant species along the reaction coordinate [67]. In the course of the reaction the changes of the net charges are analyzed taking into account the difference with the previous step [for example, Δ(TS- EtAc/MeOH coadsorbed complex) and Δ(Intermediate-TS)]. The total net atomic charge of the catalyst [calculated as Σq(Ω)catalyst] are similar for both catalyst model along the reaction coordinate. It is also observed that the total net charge always increases and is positive, that is, as the reaction progresses there is an electron transfer from the catalyst to the organic species involved in the reaction (from +0.05 e at the coadsorbed complex to +0.16/+0.17 e at the intermediate according to the catalyst model). At the beginning of the reaction, at the coadsorbed complex, MeOH gains electrons in both catalyst models (-0.05 e and -0.06 e, for [C4TA+]-6T_SiO− and [C6TA+]-10T_SiO- model respectively). On the other hand, EtAc gains electrons for the smallest model of catalyst while for the largest model it loses (-0.002 e and +0.005 e, respectively). This suggest that there is a net charge transfer of electrons from the catalyst to the reagents, but also between both reactants. In methanol, the atom with the highest charge variation is OM with a net gain of -0.11 e, while in ethylacetate H(C2), H(C3) and C3 are the ones with the highest charge variation, interestingly these atoms are involved in the interaction with OM. For example, H(C2) increase its positive charge from +0.010 e in reactants to +0.125/+0.115 e in the coadsorbed complexes (transferring electrons to OM to stabilize the complex). At the TS, interestingly the proton that is been transferred does not show significant differences, however OM decreases its net negative charge from -1.22 e to -1.07 e by transferring electrons [Δ(TS- EtAc/MeOH coadsorbed complex) = 0.14 e]. The net charge of methanol increase to +0.07/+0.06 e according to the catalyst model, that is, a net charge loss of +0.12 e on both catalyst model is observed. On the other hand, EtAc experiences a net gain of electrons of -0.21/-0.22 e increasing its negative net charge (from -0.002/+0.005 e at the coadsorbed complex to -0.21/-0.22 e at the TS). Further, H(C2), H(C3) and C3 atoms display the most important charge transfer during the reaction, followed to a lesser extent by C2 and Oc. At the adsorbed complex, the atomic charge on H(C2) is positive, and it changes to negative at the TS (decrease from +0.12 to -0.01 e) for the 6 T model, while for the 10 T model only it decreases by 0.1 e (from +0.11 to +0.02 e), because the arrangement of the atoms is different for each catalyst model. Thus, H(C2) atom transfers its electron density to C1 that is being attacked by OM. Only a small fraction of electrons comes from the catalyst (0.09e / 0.10e according to the catalyst model) indicating that, at the TS, the electrons transfer is also present between both reagents: from methanol to ethyl acetate. At the intermediate, the proton can be considered fully transferred to the catalyst and the unstable intermediate can be considered already formed. The net charge of the intermediate is -0.83 e (calculated as Σ[q(Ω)MeO − + q(Ω)EtAc]) for both catalyst model. Along the reaction coordinates, Oc gains electrons (from -1.29 e at the TS to -1.32 e at the intermediate). Interestingly, the C1 and OM atoms involved in the formed bond only experiences a slight charge variation of about 0.08 e of the global process and, the Oc atom experiences the most important charge variation of about 0.12 e of the global process. This is indicative of a stabilization by the surfactant fragment from the catalyst, which is as consequence of the weak interactions between the Oc and H atoms of the same one. 4 Conclusions In this work, we analyzed the role of the interactions involved in the reaction mechanism for the transesterification of ethyl acetate and methanol on the pore mouth of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst using QTAIM methodology. The electron density analysis allowed us to discriminate between interactions related to the reaction itself involving the bifunctional active site of the catalyst or the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion-pair, and adsorbate-catalyst interactions with the rest of the catalyst associated with the stabilization of the reactant species. All results can be summarized as follows: a) The presence of the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion-pair is key for the catalytic activity of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41. During the reaction, the silica and the head of the surfactant keep bonded through several O···H(CH3) interactions forming the bifunctional active site on the surface of the solid catalyst. The formed unstable intermediate is stabilized by both the basic and acid sites of the ion-pair. b) Four key interactions associated with the reaction mechanism were identified and quantified. At the TS, the proton being transferred is bonded to methanol and to ethyl acetate by the O1···HM···OM interaction and it is di-coordinated. The O1···HM bond forming is stronger than OM···HM bond breaking and, the proton transfer is more advanced towards the intermediate. c) The weak adsorbate-catalysts interactions along the reaction coordinate are related to the additional stabilization of both reactants on the pore mouth of the catalyst. The EtAc accommodates over the positive potential zone of the ion-pair in order to maximize and optimize the number of interactions that stabilize the coadsorbed complex and in order to fits properly for the next step of the reaction (TS formation). Over the positive potential zone of the ion-pair, four H atoms of the surfactant interact with the carbonyl oxygen atom. On the other hand, over the negative potential zone, the oxygens of silica display an opposite behavior interacting strongly with hydrogens of methanol. d) The Oc atom experiences the most important charge variation of about 0.12 e of the global process. This is indicative of a stabilization by the surfactant fragment from the catalyst, which is as consequence of the weak interactions between the Oc and H atoms of the same one. Summing up, our results indicate that the catalytic phenomenon is located on the surface of the (CTA+)(≡SiO−) ion-pair and on the nearest local surface region under both organic molecules. They also prove the key role of the intermolecular interactions between the organic molecules and the [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst in stabilizing the species along the reaction coordinate. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we analyzed the role of the interactions involved in the reaction mechanism for the transesterification of ethyl acetate and methanol on the pore mouth of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 catalyst. The Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) was applied for the analysis of adsorbate-catalyst interactions in order to gain a deeper understanding about the relationship between bonding and catalytic properties along the reaction coordinate and the role of weak interactions in the catalytic activity. Experimental FT-IR spectrum was supported by the theoretical model for the coadsorption of both reagents following a dual-site mechanism. Our results reveal that the key role of the (CTA+)(SiO−) ion pair is to stabilize the reactant species. During the reaction coordinate, the silica and the head of the surfactant are bonded through several O···H(CH3) interactions forming the bifunctional active site on the surface of the solid catalyst. Four interactions are associated with the reaction mechanism. The rest of weak adsorbate-catalysts interactions along the reaction coordinate are related to the additional stabilization of the reactants on the pore mouth of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: The key role of adsorbate-catalyst interactions into catalytic activity of [CTA+]-Si-MCM-41 from electron density analysis

dcterms:subject.$: Quantum theory of atoms in molecules
